p: Despite abovementioned intraspecific diversity, O. vulgare is still treated as a collective taxon [ 31, 32, 33, 34]. Moreover, many varieties, landraces, forms, ecotypes, and cultivars are nowadays available for stakeholders, creating possibility of subspecies misleading [ 35]. This altogether may lead to decrease homogeneity and the quality of raw material. It is especially important, since herbal products standardization requirements are taken into consideration [ 36].
